questiontext.text:
Consider the two figures shown on the coordinate grid.

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-10,8,10,-8], axis:true, showCopyright:false }); /* Original triangle */ var A = board.create('point', [{#Ax#},{#Ay#}], {name:'A', size:3}); var B = board.create('point', [{#Bx#},{#By#}], {name:'B', size:3}); var C = board.create('point', [{#Cx#},{#Cy#}], {name:'C', size:3}); board.create('polygon',[A,B,C],{ fillColor:'#a5d6a7', fillOpacity:0.6, borders:{strokeWidth:2} }); /* Image triangle */ var S = board.create('point', [{#Sx#},{#Sy#}], {name:'S', size:3}); var T = board.create('point', [{#Tx#},{#Ty#}], {name:'T', size:3}); var V = board.create('point', [{#Vx#},{#Vy#}], {name:'V', size:3}); board.create('polygon',[S,T,V],{ fillColor:'#90caf9', fillOpacity:0.6, borders:{strokeWidth:2} }); [[/jsxgraph]]

a) Are the two figures congruent?
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

b) If they are congruent, describe a sequence of transformations that maps the first figure onto the second.
[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

Use words such as: translation, rotation.

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

The two figures are congruent because all corresponding side lengths and angles are equal.

One way to map the first figure onto the second is:

  • Apply {@rot_text@}
  • Then translate the figure by the vector \(\langle {@tx@}, {@ty@} \rangle\)

Since only rigid motions (translations and rotations) are used, the figures are congruent.
